awd_titl_txt: Novel Discontinuous Galerkin Methods for Deterministic and Stochastic Optimization Problems with Inequality Constraints
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to develop new numerical methods for solving optimization problems that have applications in elasticity theory, fluid filtration in porous media, constrained heating, cancer therapy, shape optimization, and financial mathematics. The computational simulations from this project will provide insights on the understanding of complicated physical models with random perturbations. Another emphasis of this project will be the training of graduate students in numerical methods and their analysis while also training the students in theory. The students will further be trained in the efficient implementation of the computer codes so that they are better prepared for careers in industry.

The project is on the design, implementation, and rigorous analysis of a new class of discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods for variational inequalities and optimal control problems with inequality constraints that are fundamental for the modeling of nonlinear problems arising from applications in materials science, mechanical engineering, shape optimization, and financial science. Furthermore, the underlying problems may involve small parameters and random perturbations such that the complete numerical analyses are more subtle. The formulations of classical DG methods usually require large positive penalty parameters that depend on the shape regularity of the mesh and other unknown constants. The project will design novel DG methods for variational inequalities, optimal control problems with partial differential equations constraints, and related singularly perturbed and stochastically perturbed problems. Another goal of the project is to design robust, reliable, and efficient a posteriori error estimators for the corresponding deterministic and stochastic problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing and analyzing new numerical methods for solving optimization problems with inequality constraints. These types of problems are critical in fields like elasticity theory, fluid filtration in porous media, cancer therapy, shape optimization, and financial mathematics.

The research was structured around three main objectives: (1) Designing and analyzing new numerical methods including discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods for elliptic and parabolic variational inequalities; (2) Developing DG methods for optimization problems involving partial differential equations (PDEs) with inequality constraints; and (3) Investigating numerical methods for nonlinear problems, such as stochastic PDEs and variational inequalities with small or random parameters.

We explored the role of the penalty parameter in dual-wind DG methods. Our findings showed that as the penalty parameter increases, dual-wind DG solutions converge to continuous Galerkin solutions. We also applied dual-wind DG methods to Poisson’s problem and developed error estimates for approximating the Laplacian operator. In addition, we examined the connection between the DWDG method and the Ritz projection. Lastly, we extended these methods to parabolic obstacle problems, producing sharp error estimates and improving the applicability of DG methods.

We developed new DG methods to solve optimal control problems with low regularity and pointwise constraints. These methods proved to be particularly effective for both general and convection-dominated equations. By introducing techniques like discrete DG differential calculus, we simplified the implementation process and enhanced the robustness of the methods.

We introduced DG-based approaches to address problems such as fourth-order singular perturbations and stochastic Cahn-Hilliard equations. These new methods resulted in stable numerical schemes with provable convergence rates.

This project made contributions in the numerical analysis of optimization problems with inequality constraints. The methods developed in this project have wide-ranging applications in science and engineering. The project also played a key role in training students and researchers in advanced computational techniques, promoting interdisciplinary collaboration, and enhancing expertise in applied mathematics.
